frameDefinitions: A Speaker succeeds in getting an Addressee to believe or plan to execute the Content the Speaker has in mind.
A concept, Concept_1, is related causally or collocationally to another concept, Concept_2 by means of some evidence.
A Concept_1 is related to Concept_2 by some Evidence.
Using Evidence, which may or may not be expressed, a Cognizer recognizes or proves that Concept1 is associated causally or collocationally with another concept, Concept2.
A relation holds between Entity_1 and Entity_2.
A mutual social and personal relationship that keeps people involved in each other's lives comprises a Connection of Individual1 to Individual2 or between Individuals.
frameExamples: At one point, Walter tries to <t>convince</t> his wife that he has had a story accepted by BBC Radio.
The single remaining piece of evidence <t>linked</t> Kirov the tailor to Kirov the dissident activist.
I see no <t>relation</t> between these animals.
They wanted to strengthen their family <t>ties</t>.
listRoleDefinitions: The person that the Speaker seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
The wish for action on the <fen>Addressee</fen>'s part that the <fen>Speaker</fen> expresses.
A piece of written or spoken material that changes the mind of the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The general item or items that are the focus of the <fen>Content</fen> of the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s message.
When the <fen>Speaker</fen> suades the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the Speaker suades the Addressee.
The concept which is linked to <fen>Concept_2</fen>.  Generally expressed as the external argument.
The concept which is tied to <fen>Concept_1</fen>.  Generally expressed as a PP complement.
The two concepts expressed jointly.
The concept which is linked to <fen>Concept_2</fen>.
The concept which is tied to <fen>Concept_1</fen>.
The phenomenon that points to or proves the connection between <fen>Concept_1</fen> and <fen>Concept_2</fen>. Generally expressed as an external.
The two concepts expressed jointly.
<fen>Concept1</fen> is the phenomenon which is believed to be related to <fen>Concept2</fen>.
The phenomenon which is believed to be linked to Concept1.
The sentient entity that recognizes the causal connection.
The phenomena which are believed to be related.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> make the connection.
The location where the Cognizer makes the connection.
An entity with a relationship to <fen>Entity_2</fen>.
The entity with a relationship to <fen>Entity_1</fen>.
The things that are related to each other. Collective expression of the FEs <fen>Entity_1</fen> and <fen>Entity_2</fen>.
A characterization of the relation that determines what model is active for further reasoning.
<fen>Individuals</fen> have a <fen>Connection</fen> with each other.
<fen>Individual1</fen> has a social <fen>Connection</fen> to <fen>Individual_2</fen>.
<fen>Individual2</fen> has a relationship to <fen>Individual_1</fen>.
<fen>Connection</fen> is the personal relationship between <fen>Individuals</fen> that keeps them involved in each other's lives.
listRoleExamples: <fex>His speech</fex> convinced me to join the Peace Corps.
You haven't convinced me <fex>about that yet</fex>.
High death rates among smokers connect <fex>cigarettes</fex> with disease.
Skid marks on the street connects my neighbor's car <fex>to my broken mailbox</fex>.
Ample evidence is able to connect <fex>the two</fex>.
<fex>This topic</fex> has no relation to the matter at hand.
This topic has no relation <fex>to the matter at hand</fex>.
The relation <fex>between these data sets</fex> is not clear to me.
There is a <fex>kinship</fex> relation between them .

passageCandidateSpans.text: The Dungeon Master refuting any connection with D&D

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The Disappearance of James Dallas Egbert III (Part II
